title: 115_hr2493
content: The Act may be cited as the "Conflicts from Political Fundraising Act of 2017". Since the 2010 Citizens United v. FEC decision, corporate political spending has significantly increased, leading to concerns about conflicts of interest when nominees or appointees have ties to political entities. Contributions to organizations under sections 501(c)(4) and 501(c)(6) of the IRS code may pose risks of actual or perceived conflicts of interest. Current financial disclosure requirements do not mandate reporting donations to political action committees or entities under sections 501(c)(4) or 501(c)(6) of the IRS code, allowing for anonymous political spending. To address conflicts of interest, public disclosure to the Office of Government Ethics is recommended for negotiation of ethics agreements. SEC. 3. DISCLOSURE OF CERTAIN TYPES OF CONTRIBUTIONS. Definitions in the Ethics in Government Act of 1978 are amended to include the term 'covered contribution' as a payment or deposit of money made by or on behalf of a covered individual to a political organization or specific types of organizations. The curr_chunk discusses organizations exempt from tax under section 501(c) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 that promote or oppose changes in Federal laws or regulations related to the agency where a covered individual is nominated or serving. The curr_chunk specifies that activities subject to Federal laws or regulations administered by the agency where a covered individual is nominated or serving can be disclosed to political organizations or tax-exempt organizations under specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The curr_chunk defines a 'covered individual' as someone nominated or appointed to a specific position under certain sections of the United States Code. The curr_chunk specifies positions that qualify as 'covered individuals' under the United States Code, excluding certain positions and individuals. The curr_chunk amends disclosure requirements under the Ethics in Government Act of 1978, specifying that individuals assuming covered positions must file a report within 30 days. The curr_chunk introduces amendments to disclosure requirements in the Ethics in Government Act of 1978, mandating individuals in covered positions to file reports promptly. This includes adding information specified in section 102(j) and adjusting subsections (d) and (e) accordingly. Additionally, changes are made to section 102(g) regarding political campaign funds. The amendments to the Ethics in Government Act of 1978 require covered individuals to file reports on gifts and contributions. Covered gifts include those made to covered individuals, their spouses, or dependent children by specified entities. Reports must include details of covered contributions made or solicited during the applicable period. The Ethics in Government Act of 1978 mandates covered individuals to report gifts and contributions received. Covered contributions, if made or solicited by a covered individual, may pose a conflict of interest. The Director of the Office of Government Ethics can exempt a contribution if it does not present a conflict of interest risk. The Ethics in Government Act of 1978 requires covered individuals to report gifts received. The Director of the Office of Government Ethics must provide reports and ethics agreements to Congress upon request. Rules on ethics agreements will be issued by the Director promptly. Government Ethics will issue rules on how executive branch agencies should handle disclosed information when drafting ethics agreements with appointed individuals. Amendments are made to the Ethics in Government Act of 1978, including changes to specific sections. Amendments are made to various sections of the Ethics in Government Act of 1978, including changes to section numbers such as 109(15), 109(16), and 109(11). Additionally, amendments are made to the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. Amendments to the Ethics in Government Act of 1978 involve changes to section numbers, including 109(8), 109(10), and 109(16) in various subparagraphs. Additionally, section 499(j)(2) of the Public Health Service Act is also amended.
